sen.j: 寂光院（じゃっこういん）は、京都市左京区大原にある天台宗の寺院。
sen.e: Jakko-in Temple is a Tendai Sect Buddhist temple located in Ohara, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Jakko-in Temple is a Tendai Sect Buddhist temple located in Ohara, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Jakko-in Temple is a Tendai Sect Buddhist temple located in Ohara, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 山号を清香山と称する。
sen.e: Its honorific mountain prefix is 'Seikozan'.
Its honorific mountain prefix is 'Seikozan.'
Its honorific mountain prefix is 'Seikozan.'

sen.j: 寺号は玉泉寺。
sen.e: The temple's title is 'Gyokusen-ji Temple'.
The temple's title is 'Gyokusen-ji Temple.'
The temple's title is 'Gyokusen-ji Temple.'

sen.j: 本尊は地蔵菩薩、開基（創立者）は聖徳太子と伝える。
sen.e: It was founded by Prince Shotoku and is devoted to the principal image Ksitigarbha.
It was founded by Prince Shotoku and is devoted to the principal image Ksitigarbha.
It was founded by Prince Shotoku and is devoted to the principal image Ksitigarbha.

sen.j: 平清盛の娘・建礼門院が、平家滅亡後隠棲した所であり、『平家物語』ゆかりの寺として知られる。
sen.e: The temple is well known as the place where TAIRA no Kiyomori's daughter Kenrei Mon-in lived in seclusion after the defeat of the Taira forces and is closely connected to "The Tale of the Heike".
sen.cmt: ・Kenrei Mon-in: http://kaiwai.city.kyoto.jp/search/view_sight.php?ManageCode=1000136&InforKindCode=1・lived in seclusion: 新和英大辞典・the defeat of the Taira forces: http://kaiwai.city.kyoto.jp/search/view_sight.php?ManageCode=1000136&InforKindCode=1・"The Tale of the Heike": http://kaiwai.city.kyoto.jp/search/view_sight.php?ManageCode=1000136&InforKindCode=1
sen.e: The temple is well known as the place where TAIRA no Kiyomori's daughter Kenrei Mon-in lived in seclusion after the defeat of the Heike family and is closely connected to "The Tale of the Heike."
sen.cmt: 平家→Heike familyピリオドを移動。
sen.e: The temple is well known as the place where TAIRA no Kiyomori's daughter Kenrei Mon-in lived in seclusion after the defeat of the Taira family and is closely connected to "The Tale of the Heike."
sen.cmt: 統一用語の指示にしたがい、平家＝the Taira familyにしました。

sen.j: 起源と歴史
sen.e: Origin and History
Origin and History
Origin and History

sen.j: 寂光院の草創について、明確なことはわかっていない。
sen.e: The origin of Jakko-in Temple is not known for sure.
The origin of Jakko-in Temple is not known for sure.
The origin of Jakko-in Temple is not known for sure.

sen.j: 寺伝では推古天皇2年（594年）、聖徳太子が父用明天皇の菩提のため開創したとされ、太子の乳母玉照姫（恵善尼）が初代住職であるという。
sen.e: According to temple legend, it was established in the year 594 by Prince Shotoku to pray for the soul of his late father, Emperor Yomei and the first abbess is said to have been the prince's wet nurse, Tamateru-hime (Ezen-ni).

According to temple legend, it was established in the year 594 by Prince Shotoku to pray for the soul of his late father, Emperor Yomei and the first abbess is said to have been the prince's wet nurse, Tamateru-hime (Ezen-ni).

According to temple legend, it was established in the year 594 by Prince Shotoku to pray for the soul of his late father, Emperor Yomei and the first abbess is said to have been the prince's wet nurse, Tamateru-hime (Ezen-ni).

sen.j: しかし、江戸時代の地誌には空海開基説（『都名所図会』）、11世紀末に大原に隠棲し大原声明を完成させた融通念仏の祖良忍が開いたとの説（『京羽二重』）もある。
sen.e: However, there is also the Edo period theory published in "To Meisho Zue" that names Kukai as founder and an alternative theory published in "Kyohabutae" that it was founded by Yuzu-nenbutsu founder, Runin who secluded himself in Ohara.

However, there is also the Edo period theory published in "To Meisho Zue" that names Kukai as founder and an alternative theory published in "Kyohabutae" that it was founded by Yuzu-Nembutsu founder, Ryonin who secluded himself in Ohara and completed Ohara shomyo (Buddhist hymns) in the end of the 11th century.
sen.cmt: nenbutsu→NembutsuRunin→Ryonin"11世紀末に"と"大原声明を完成させた"部分が抜けているので補足。
sen.e: However, there is also the Edo period theory published in "To Meisho Zue" that names Kukai as founder and an alternative theory published in "Kyohabutae" that it was founded by Yuzu-Nenbutsu founder, Ryonin who secluded himself in Ohara and completed Ohara shomyo (Buddhist hymns) in the end of the 11th century.

sen.j: 哲学者梅原猛は、大原が小野妹子の領地であったことなどから、聖徳太子開基もありうるとしている。
sen.e: The philosopher Takeshi UMEHARA claimed that it is possible that the temple was founded by Prince Shotoku as Ohara was the territory of ONO no Imoko.
The philosopher Takeshi UMEHARA claimed that it is possible that the temple was founded by Prince Shotoku as Ohara was the territory of ONO no Imoko.
The philosopher Takeshi UMEHARA claimed that it is possible that the temple was founded by Prince Shotoku as Ohara was the territory of ONO no Imoko.

sen.j: 現在、寂光院はそうした草創伝説よりも、『平家物語』に登場する建礼門院隠棲のゆかりの地として知られている。
sen.e: Today temple is better known as the place in which Kenrei Mon-in lived in seclusion as described in "The Tale of the Heike".
sen.cmt: ・Kenrei Mon-in: http://kaiwai.city.kyoto.jp/search/view_sight.php?ManageCode=1000136&InforKindCode=1・lived in seclusion: 新和英大辞典・"The Tale of the Heike": http://kaiwai.city.kyoto.jp/search/view_sight.php?ManageCode=1000136&InforKindCode=1
sen.e: Today temple is better known as the place in which Kenrei Mon-in lived in seclusion as described in "The Tale of the Heike."
Today the temple is better known as the place in which Kenrei Mon-in lived in seclusion as described in "The Tale of the Heike."

sen.j: 建礼門院徳子（1155－1213）は平清盛の娘、高倉天皇の中宮で、安徳天皇の生母である。
sen.e: Kenrei Mon-in Tokuko (115-1213) was the daughter of TAIRA no Kiyomori, empress of Emperor Takakura and the mother of Emperor Antoku.
Kenrei Mon-in Tokuko (1155-1213) was the daughter of TAIRA no Kiyomori, empress of Emperor Takakura and the mother of Emperor Antoku.
Kenrei Mon-in Tokuko (1155-1213) was the daughter of TAIRA no Kiyomori, empress of Emperor Takakura and the mother of Emperor Antoku.

sen.j: 寿永4年（1185年）、壇ノ浦で平家一族が滅亡した後も生き残り、侍女の阿波内侍とともに尼となって寂光院で余生を送った。
sen.e: After surviving the destruction of the entire Heike clan at Dan-no-Ura in 1185, she entered the nunnery at Jakko-in Temple with her lady-in-waiting, Awa no naiji where she spent the remainder of her life.

After surviving the destruction of the entire Heike family at Dan-no-Ura in 1185, she entered the nunnery at Jakko-in Temple with her lady-in-waiting, Awa no naiji where she spent the remainder of her life.
sen.cmt: 指示に従い、平家→Heike familyに訂正。
sen.e: After surviving the destruction of the entire Taira family at Dan-no-Ura in 1185, she entered the nunnery at Jakko-in Temple with her lady-in-waiting, Awa no naiji where she spent the remainder of her life.
sen.cmt: 統一用語リストに従い、平家＝the Taira familyに。

sen.j: 寂光院や三千院のある大原の里は、念仏行者の修行の地であり、貴人の隠棲の地であった。
sen.e: The village of Ohara in which Jakko-in Temple and Sanzen-in Temple are located was a place Nembutsu was practiced and aristocrats secluded themselves.
The village of Ohara in which Jakko-in Temple and Sanzen-in Temple are located was a place Nembutsu was practiced and aristocrats secluded themselves.
The village of Ohara in which Jakko-in Temple and Sanzen-in Temple are located was a place Nembutsu was practiced and aristocrats secluded themselves.

sen.j: 平家一門と高倉・安徳両帝の冥福をひたすら祈っていた建礼門院をたずねて後白河天皇が寂光院を訪れるのは文治2年（1186年）のことで、この故事は『平家物語』の「大原御幸」の段において語られ、物語のテーマである「諸行無常」を象徴するエピソードとして人々に愛読された。
sen.e: Emperor Go-Shirakawa's 1186 visit to Kenrei Mon-in, who was praying for the souls of members of the Taira clan and Emperors Takakura and Antoku at Jakko-in Temple, is recorded in the "Ohara Goko" paragraph of "The Tale of the Heike", which has been fondly read for the story's theme that symbolizes the transience of worldly things.
sen.cmt: ・"Ohara Goko": http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/kazuoy/kanjyo.html・"The Tale of the Heike": http://kaiwai.city.kyoto.jp/search/view_sight.php?ManageCode=1000136&InforKindCode=1
sen.e: Emperor Go-Shirakawa's 1186 visit to Kenrei Mon-in, who was praying for the souls of members of the Taira family and Emperors Takakura and Antoku at Jakko-in Temple, is recorded in the 'Ohara Goko' paragraph of "The Tale of the Heike," which has been fondly read for the story's theme that symbolizes the transience of worldly things.

Emperor Go-Shirakawa's 1186 visit to Kenrei Mon-in, who was praying for the souls of members of the Taira family and Emperors Takakura and Antoku at Jakko-in Temple, is recorded in the 'Ohara Goko' paragraph of "The Tale of the Heike," which has been fondly read for the story's theme that symbolizes the transience of worldly things.

sen.j: 境内
sen.e: Temple Grounds
Temple Grounds
Temple Grounds

sen.j: 本堂は淀殿（淀君）の命で片桐且元が慶長年間（1596－1615）再興したものであったが、平成12年(2000年)5月9日の不審火で焼失した。
sen.e: The main hall was rebuilt by Katsumoto KATAGIRI during the Keicho era (1586-1615) under the order of Yodo-dono (Yodogimi), but was destroyed by arson on May 9th, 2000.
The main hall was rebuilt by Katsumoto KATAGIRI during the Keicho era (1596-1615) under the order of Yodo-dono (Yodogimi), but was destroyed by arson on May 9, 2000.
The main hall was rebuilt by Katsumoto KATAGIRI during the Keicho era (1596-1615) under the order of Yodo-dono (Yodogimi), but was destroyed by arson on May 9, 2000.

sen.j: この際、本尊の地蔵菩薩立像（重文）も焼損し、堂内にあった建礼門院と阿波内侍の張り子像（建礼門院の手紙や写経を使用して作ったものという）も焼けてしまった。
sen.e: At this time the principal image standing statue of Ksitigarbha (Important Cultural Property) was also burnt along with the papier-mâché statues of Kenrei Mon-in and Awa no naiji (created from the letters and sutra transcriptions written by Kanrei Mon-in).

At this time the principal image standing statue of Ksitigarbha (Important Cultural Property) was also burnt along with the papier-mâshé statues of Kenrei Mon-in and Awa no naiji (created from the letters and sutra transcriptions written by Kanrei Mon-in).
sen.cmt: âとéがフランス語の為書体が変わります。trans 1ではAcademy Engraved LETが使用されていまうが、Helveticaの方が一般的なので変更しました。判断をお任せします。
sen.e: At this time the principal image standing statue of Ksitigarbha (Important Cultural Property) was also burnt along with the papier-mâshé statues of Kenrei Mon-in and Awa no naiji (created from the letters and sutra transcriptions written by Kanrei Mon-in).

sen.j: 現在の本堂は平成17年(2005年)6月再建された。
sen.e: The current main hall was rebuilt in June 2005.
The current main hall was rebuilt in June 2005.
The current main hall was rebuilt in June 2005.

sen.j: 同時に新しく作られた本尊や建礼門院と阿波内侍の像も安置されている。
sen.e: It houses replicas of the principal image and statues of Kenrei Mon-in and Awa no naiji that were produced at the same time.
It houses replicas of the principal image and statues of Kenrei Mon-in and Awa no naiji that were produced at the same time.
It houses replicas of the principal image and statues of Kenrei Mon-in and Awa no naiji that were newly produced at the same time.

sen.j: 宝物殿は「松智鳳殿」という名称で、平成18年（2006年）10月に開館した。
sen.e: The museum named 'Hochisho-den' was opened in October 2006.
The Treasure Hall named 'Hochisho-den' was opened in October 2006.
The Treasure Hall named 'Hochisho-den' was opened in October 2006.

sen.j: 建礼門院の陵墓はもともと境内地にあったが、明治以降は宮内省（現・宮内庁）の管理下に移り、境内から切り離されている。
sen.e: The tomb of Kenrei Mon-in was originally located within the temple grounds but fell under the control of the Department of the Imperial Household (the present Imperial Household Agency) and was separated from the precinct.

The tomb of Kenrei Mon-in was originally located within the temple grounds but fell under the control of the Department of the Imperial Household (the present Imperial Household Agency) and was separated from the precinct.

The tomb of Kenrei Mon-in was originally located within the temple grounds but fell under the control of the Department of the Imperial Household (the present Imperial Household Agency) and was separated from the precinct.

sen.j: 文化財
sen.e: Cultural Properties
Cultural Properties
Cultural Properties

sen.j: 地蔵菩薩立像（重文）－当寺の旧本尊である。
sen.e: Standing statue of Ksitigarbha (Important Cultural Property): The temple's former principal image.
Standing statue of Ksitigarbha (Important Cultural Property): The temple's former principal image.
Standing statue of Ksitigarbha (Important Cultural Property): The temple's former principal image.

sen.j: 寛喜元年（1229年）の作で、像高256センチの大作である。
sen.e: It was created in 1229 and large at 256cm tall.
It was created in 1229 and large at 256cm tall.
It was created in 1229 and large at 256cm tall.

sen.j: 像内に3,000体以上の地蔵菩薩の小像ほか、多くの納入品を納めていた。
sen.e: The statue contained over 3,000 smaller Ksitigarbha statues as well as many other items.
The statue contained over 3,000 smaller Ksitigarbha statues as well as many other items.
The statue contained over 3,000 smaller Ksitigarbha statues as well as many other items.

sen.j: 2000年に起きた本堂の火災の際、（2007年5月9日時効成立）本体は焼損したが、像内納入品は無事で、現在も「木造地蔵菩薩立像（焼損）」の名称で、像内納入品ともども重要文化財に継続して指定されている。
sen.e: The statue was burnt in the fire that broke out at the main hall in 2000 (prescription period until May 9th, 2007), but the items inside the statue were unaffected and continue to be designated Important Cultural Properties under the name 'Wooden Standing Statue of Ksitigarbha (damaged by a fire)'.
sen.cmt: ・Important Cultural Properties: 新和英大辞典
sen.e: The statue was burnt in the fire that broke out at the main hall in 2000 (prescription period until May 9, 2007), but the items inside the statue were unaffected and continue to be designated Important Cultural Properties under the name 'Wooden Standing Statue of Ksitigarbha (damaged by a fire).'

The statue was burnt in the fire that broke out at the main hall in 2000 (prescription period until May 9, 2007), but the items inside the statue were unaffected and continue to be designated Important Cultural Properties under the name 'Wooden Standing Statue of Ksitigarbha (damaged by a fire).'

sen.j: 現在は本堂よりも高台にある収蔵庫に安置され、特定日のみ一般に公開される。
sen.e: They are now housed within the repository located on higher ground than the main hall and only displayed on certain days.
They are now housed within the repository located on higher ground than the main hall and only displayed on certain days.
They are now housed within the repository located on higher ground than the main hall and only displayed on certain days.

sen.j: なお、新しい本尊像は財団法人美術院国宝修理所によって3年半をかけて制作され、2005年に完成した。
sen.e: The new principal image statue was created at the Nihon Bijutsuin (the Japan Art Institute) National Treasure Repair Center over a period of 3.5 years and completed in 2005.
The new principal image statue was created at the Nihon Bijutsuin (the Japan Art Institute) National Treasure Repair Center over a period of 3.5 years and completed in 2005.
The new principal image statue was created at the Nihon Bijutsuin (the Japan Art Institute) National Treasure Repair Center over a period of 3.5 years and completed in 2005.

sen.j: ヒノキ材の寄木造で、旧本尊の新造時の姿を忠実に模している。
sen.e: It is assembled from pieces of Japanese cypress wood and true to how the former principal image would have looked at the time of its completion.
sen.cmt: ・Japanese cypress: アドバンストフェイバリット和英辞典
sen.e: It is assembled from pieces of Japanese cypress wood and true to how the former principal image would have looked at the time of its completion.
It is assembled from pieces of Japanese cypress wood and true to how the former principal image would have looked at the time of its completion.

sen.j: 建礼門院と阿波内侍の像は、もともと張り子像であったが、今回木造で作り直された。
sen.e: The statues of Kenrei Mon-in and Awa no naiji were originally made of papier-mâché but the replicas were created in wood.
The statues of Kenrei Mon-in and Awa no naiji were originally made of papier-mâshé but the replicas were created in wood.
sen.cmt: âとéがフランス語の為書体が変わります。trans 1ではAcademy Engraved LETが使用されていまうが、Helveticaの方が一般的なので変更しました。
sen.e: The statues of Kenrei Mon-in and Awa no naiji were originally made of papier-mâshé but the replicas were created in wood.
